text:
- [Rob] The Cost Optimizer
for Amazon WorkSpaces

analyzes all of your
Amazon WorkSpace usage data
and automatically converts the WorkSpace
to the most cost effective billing option
depending on your individual usage.

You can use this AWS solution
with a single account

or with AWS organizations
across multiple accounts.

We're pleased to announce
the Cost Optimizer
for Amazon WorkSpaces version 2.7,

which includes numerous
enhancements implemented
based on direct customer feedback.
In this video, we'll demonstrate

how to deploy the Cost
Optimizer for Amazon WorkSpaces,

how to use CloudWatch
dashboards for insights,

how to review daily summaries,
identifying user sessions,
and we'll talk about the next steps
when deploying the solution.
To get started, here's Dave Jaskie,

an EUC specialist solutions
architect with AWS,
to guide you through the deployment steps.
- [Dave] Thanks, Rob.
First, we'll navigate
to the WorkSpaces Cost Optimizer solution.
This page contains detailed information
on the architecture implementation,
as well as other steps for deployment.

Right side, you can view
the CloudFormation template,
as well as the Implementation Guide.

The Implementation Guide covers
several deployment scenarios
for the WorkSpaces Cost Optimizer.
After reviewing the Implementation Guide,
click on the CloudFormation template.

For this scenario, we'll
do a hub account setup.
Click on the View Template

and that will download the
template for the next step
when we go back into the AWS console.
Now return to the AWS console.
We'll choose an existing template
and select Upload template file,

and we'll use the file
that was just downloaded
in the previous step.

For the parameters, start
by entering a stack name.
For this deployment, we'll keep it simple
and deployed in a new VPC.

For additional options,
please review the admin guide.
For the VPC settings,
we'll leave everything at the default
and scroll down to the testing parameters.

For this deployment, we'll
launch in dry run mode.

This will not make any
changes to the WorkSpace.
In addition, we'll simulate

the end of the month
cleanup in here as well.

As we scroll through
the pricing parameters,
we'll leave this at the defaults as well.

For additional information,
see the WorkSpaces pricing.

For the AWS regions,
we'll leave this blank

to get all the regions where
WorkSpaces are deployed.
In addition, we'll not do terminations.

Finally, we'll do a
single account deployment.

At the next screen,
we'll review information
for the CloudFormation template.

Finally, we'll review the
parameters that we've set up
for the CloudFormation template.
At the bottom, we'll click Acknowledge
and then click Submit.

The CloudFormation is now
deploying into your account.

You can click the refresh
button to watch the events

for the CloudFormation
template deployment.
Please wait 'til this is complete
before going to the next steps.

Now that you have the
Cost Optimizer deployed,

we'll take a look at
the CloudWatch dashboard
that was generated.

If you just recently
deployed the Cost Optimizer,
the EventBridge rule needs to run once
before the data becomes available.
By default, this is once per day,

and you can view the details
in Amazon EventBridge.
Switching back to the console,

we can see the WorkSpaces
that are deployed.

In this case, 31 between
a few different regions
in my account.
We can see they have different hourly
versus monthly billing.
As we scroll down,

we can see some additional
historical information as well.

As this runs, we'll get
additional information

that will populate in
this dashboard as well.
In addition to the CloudWatch dashboards,

you will get daily
reports on the WorkSpaces.

We will show you here how we
can take a look at the data

and make decisions on
WorkSpaces running mode,

compute, and volumes that you
have deployed to your users.

In the S3 console, we'll
first select the year,
then we'll select the month,

and then the date that we're
looking for the report.

This will show a detailed
report for each directory,
as well as an aggregation report
for all the WorkSpaces that are deployed.

For this, we'll click on
the aggregated dry run
end of the month report.
At the next window, we'll click Download,

and this will download a copy
of the report to my desktop.
When the WorkSpace report is open,

there'll be a column
for the change reported.
This column is for showing the WorkSpace

that should be changed
between always on or hourly.

The next column has
information on the bundle type,

as well as the initial mode
for the start of the month,
as well as the mode for the next month.
As we move down,

each of the columns will
have additional information
on that WorkSpaces instance.

Further down, we have
information on the CPU usage,
the memory usage,

as well as the volume usage
within that WorkSpace.
Using this information,

you can make decisions on
increasing the compute type
to provide a better experience
or decreasing for cost savings.
In addition, details are provided
on the volumes for planning increases
to the WorkSpaces instances.

Finally, there's
information that's captured

on the average packet loss,
as well as in session latency
for planning additional regions.
We just showed you how you can take a look

at the aggregated data
for a specific WorkSpace.

If you're looking to dive deeper
in a specific user session,
that data is available as well.
This may be useful to dive into a user
that may be reporting an issue.

With the Cost Optimizer, you
have detailed information
on that specific user session

with the average latency,
packet loss, CPU memory,
as well as volume information.

To get detailed information
on the sessions,

go to the AWS console and
go to the Dynamo DB service,
and then click on the User Sessions table.

Once it loads, we'll click
on the Explore table items,
and this will give us a row for each
of the individual sessions
that have been signed into WorkSpaces.

For each of the sessions
that we have out there,

we'll have information on
the start time, the end time,
along with all the detailed metrics
for that individual session.

This includes CPU memory,
in session latency,
UDP packet loss,

along with information on
the root and user volume.

Using this data will help
you get quick insight

into a user session,
as well as any factors

that may have been
causing a poor experience.
